subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: ... It s a problem, yes.  On one theory, you need to learn which is conventionally used for which, as in the traditional orthography; on the other theory, you
messageBody:
Ted Larson Freeman scripsit:

> I pronounce "ah" and "awe" exactly the same. It's exactly the same
> sound I use for the first vowel in "nautical". For me, any distinction
> between QS letters #32, #33 and #34 is difficult to even imagine. This
> has been a stumbling block for me in trying to learn QS. I don't have
> a good way to guess which of these letters would be most appropriate
> to use for sounds that I cannot distinguish.

It's a problem, yes. On one theory, you need to learn which is
conventionally used for which, as in the traditional orthography; on the
other theory, you should use Ah for all, and other people will have to
put up with reading "ahx" and "nahtical" (or their QS analogues).

Most people who have Ah = Awe = Ox merged can make the sound that
others use for "awe" by saying "Awwwwwwwwww!!", as in what you say when
something is really cute. That is a sound, not really a word, and it
hasn't changed. A very short version of that is the vowel of "ox".

Different anglophones have different mergers, of course. You merge all
three; for me, Ox = Ah but Awe is separate. In Canada, Awe = Ah but Ox
is separate. Outside North America, all three are separate.

--
Here lies the Christian, John Cowan
judge, and poet Peter, http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
Who broke the laws of God cowan@...
and man and metre.
